text: in Thailand an operation has begun to
rescue the 12 boys in their football
coach from the flooded cave where
they've been trapped for the last
fortnight the head of the rescue mission
said it could take up to four days to
bring them all out that's depending on
the weather and the weather isn't good
as we can see from talking to Sophie
long our correspondent at the mouth of
the cave and we can see how hard it's
raining there Sophie and that is exactly
why the rescue had to begin now because
if the the rains got worse and worse in
their coming days then the water levels
inside the cave would rise that's
exactly right then yeah the governor of
Trang write province who's leading this
operation called this a war against
water it's always been a race against
time but that has become more and more
critical over the past few days it is
monsoon season and the fear was that if
they didn't move now that the rains the
water that they've pumped out of the
cave hundreds of millions of litres they
pumped out of the cave over the past few
days the water levels in the cave now at
the lowest they have been for ten days
and the fear was that the play left
there any longer water would rush down
the mountain and refill it potentially
leaving the boys and even worse
conditions and they found themselves in
the first place now this will be a
lengthy operation it got underway four
hours ago we will have no indication of
how successful it a thin for at least
another seven hours we're told that each
of the boys will take at least 11 hours
to be brought out of the cave they'll be
led out by two expert divers there's 13
in international which they called them
all-star divers that are leading this
operation backed up by five Thai Navy
SEAL divers and there will be points
along the way where the boys can rest
and they will be medically assessed and
checked that they are capable of going
on we were told by the guy leading
operation that their hearts are strong
and that they are determined their
families have obviously been told and
they said they agreed that the mission
should start now but it is not without
its risks there are 13 young lives at
stake here in a rescue attempt that has
already claimed one life yeah not
without risk and obviously the families
holding their breath throughout the
world really watching this extraordinary
rescue operation holding it
breath how exactly are they going to get
these boys out because we know that some
of them are as young as 11 they can't
even swim yeah well they have prepared
for it as best they can since they were
found on Monday they have been having
swimming lessons in the cave they've
been experimenting with dive mask we're
told that they'll have full dive mask so
breathing for them will be as easy as
possible they've kind of cleared out any
obstacles they can with jackhammers
taking out the jagged edges as best they
can and now they will be led by two
expert divers which hold that the curse
the level of water has reduced
significantly there are parts of the
cave which they'll just be able to float
along the top we don't know happening
confirm how much diving they will have
to do but some of these boys can't swim
none of them have any diving experience
and as it was underlined by the tragic
death of a former Thai Navy SEAL two
nights ago he was making what for him
would have been a 5-hour journey out of
the cave having delivered oxygen tanks
to the chamber he lost consciousness and
it was impossible to revive him so on
that day just two days ago a real
highlight really the dangers that these
boys are facing it is a high-risk
operation but they failed as you can see
that they were left with no other choice
and they have really agonized long and
hard about this happen day because one
alternative proposal was to wait a few
months until the end of the rainy season
[Applause]
yeah that was one option on the table
because the only safe way to bring them
out was the way that they came in by
walking that at the moment has been
possible and it was thought initially
for the perhaps the best thing to do was
to sit and wait but in the past few days
there's been concerns about the air
quality inside the cave now oxygen
levels drop to 15% they have connected
an air pipe which has brought those back
up again but what they don't know is how
much water will fall over the next days
weeks or months and it's possible the
work case scenario would that they would
be cut off again and it would be
impossible to get food into them
the other option on the table was to
drill down
now more than a hundred holes have been
drilled in the mountain behind me some
of them to improve the air quality in
the cave but the world's hoped
potentially that they could reach the
boys that way and bring them out through
the top down again though would take
time you'd need to get heavy drilling
equipment up the mountain they probably
need to build new roads in order to do
that so this has always been a race
against time a race against the weather
and it was felt this morning that
conditions would not get any better so
they've started the operation it will go
on for several days and Sophie yesterday
to emerge that the boys had written
letters to their families saying you
know they were okay not to worry
and also the football coach writing to
the parents apologizing for getting the
boys into the cave in the first place
yeah so these were messages that were
brought out by Thai Navy SEALs who've
been into the cave delivering supplies
they bought messages out one of them as
you say was from the coach he's just 25
years old himself it's the first time we
heard of him but he said to the parents
I'm really sorry and he promised that he
would do his best to look after boys and
reassured them that they've been treated
so well by all the rescue workers that
have reached them and some really really
sweet messages from the boys themselves
given their ages and their predicament
one of them called turn just said don't
worry about turn turn can look after
himself
others were much more concerned about
the food so they were going to get when
they came out lots of requests for their
favorite food to be cooked by their
grandmothers and other pleas to teachers
not to send them too much homework and
one boy said with parents don't worry
about me I'll be back but don't forget
about my birthday party so we've heard
from the rescue workers that their
spirits are high we've also know that
letters from their parents have been
taken into the boys and hope to boost
their morale ahead of this rescue
operation because they're going to have
to be pretty brave I think over the next
48 72 hours all right Sophie thank you
very much indeed for bringing us the
very latest there from northern Thailand
Sophie long report
